elements.content: Four three-dimensional (3D) Cd­(II)/Mn­(II) coordination polymers, namely, {[Mn1.5(TCPB)­(H2O)­(μ2-OH2)]­·H2O} n (1), {[Cd3.5(TCPB)2­(H2O)3­(μ2-OH2)­(μ3-OH)]­·H2O} n (2), [Mn1.5(TCPB)­(bib)0.5­(DMF)] n (3), and {[Cd2(TCPB)­(HCOO)­(bib)­(H2O)]­·0.5dioxane} n (4), have been constructed from the flexible tripodal ligand of 1,3,5-tris­(4-carbonylphenyloxy)­benzene (H3TCPB) with or without the help of bib auxiliary linker (bib = 1,4-bis­(imidazol-1-yl)­benzene). On the basis of the one-dimensional (1D) rod-like {Mn3(COO)8­(μ2-H2O)2} n secondary building units (SBUs), complex 1 displays a 3D (4,8)-connected flu net with the point symbol of {412.612.84}­{46}2. Complex 2 shows a novel 3D 12-connected {312.440.512.62} net based on the 1D {Cd6(COO)12­(μ3-OH)2­(μ2-OH2)2} n SBUs. When the bib bridging ancillary linker was introduced, a trinuclear {Mn3(COO)6} SBU based 2-fold interpenetrated 3D (3,8)-connected {43}2{46.618.84}-tfz-d net for 3, and a binuclear {Cd2(COO)3} SBU based 3D (3,7)-connected {4.62}­{47.614} net with interesting self-penetrating features for 4 were obtained. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities of 1 and 3 have been investigated. The results display the antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between the adjacent MnII ions of the SBUs in 1 and 3. Fluorescence measurements show 2 and 4 have highly selective and sensitive detection for Cr3+ cations in aqueous solution and nitrobenzene derivatives in DMF.

elements.content: On the basis of the flexible tripodal ligand of 1,3,5-tris­(4-carbonylphenyloxy)­benzene, four three-dimensional (3D) Mn­(II)/Cd­(II) coordination polymers have been obtained with the structure ranging from a 3D (4,8)-connected flu net, 3D 12-connected {312.440.512.62} net, 2-fold interpenetrated 3D (3,8)-connected tfz-d net, to 3D (3,7)-connected {4.62}­{47.614} net. The magnetic measurements indicate that 1 and 3 have antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between the adjacent MnII ions of the SBUs. And the fluorescence measurements show 2 and 4 exhibit highly sensitive and selective detection for Cr3+ cation and nitrobenzene derivatives (nitrobenzene, p-nitrotoluene, p-nitroaniline, and p-nitrophenol).

elements.content: Functional coordination polymers (CPs), as one of the most important components of the inorganic–organic hybird materials, have drawn more and more attentions for their interesting self-assembly modular structures and gigantic potential applications in the fields of single molecular magnet (SMM), molecule sensing and fluorescent probes, catalysis and photocatalysis, molecular switches, electronic devices, etc. As we all known, the method of organic linkers connected metal ions to form such materials will deeply affect those properties and applications. Thus, the strategy of building functional CPs through the rational choice and design of organic linkers has proven to be an efficient routine.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Functional coordination polymers (CPs), as one of the most important components of the inorganic-organic hybird materials, have drawn more and more attentions for their interesting self-assembly modular structures and gigantic potential applications in the fields of single molecular magnet (SMM), molecule sensing and fluorescent probes, catalysis and photocatalysis, molecular switches, electronic devices, etc. As we all known, the method of organic linkers connected metal ions to form such materials will deeply affect those properties and applications. Thus, the strategy of building functional CPs through the rational choice and design of organic linkers has proven to be an efficient routine.

elements.content: Benefitting from flexible backbones and more freedom in the process of coordinating with metal ions, flexible ligands have been widely selected in the building of functional CPs. It is noteworthy that CPs based on the flexible ligands exhibit breathtaking crystal structural transformations in the solid state, which are known as single crystal to single crystal (SC–SC) transformation. Moreover, such CPs show interesting “breathing effects” sometimes, which may greatly improve the performances of CPs in terms of adsorption and separation, sensing, and shape memory. Thus, the design of flexible ligands is very meaningful and can generate functional CPs with highly selective adsorption and sensing for molecules.
elements.clean_text: Benefitting from flexible backbones and more freedom in the process of coordinating with metal ions, flexible ligands have been widely selected in the building of functional CPs. It is noteworthy that CPs based on the flexible ligands exhibit breathtaking crystal structural transformations in the solid state, which are known as single crystal to single crystal (SC-SC) transformation. Moreover, such CPs show interesting "breathing effects" sometimes, which may greatly improve the performances of CPs in terms of adsorption and separation, sensing, and shape memory. Thus, the design of flexible ligands is very meaningful and can generate functional CPs with highly selective adsorption and sensing for molecules.

elements.content: Inspired by the above considerations, we designed four CPs by selecting the flexible tripodal ligand of 1,3,5-tris­(4-carbonylphenyloxy)­benzene (H3TCPB) with or without the help of a bib auxiliary linker. Herein, four three-dimensional (3D) CPs with diverse SBUs have been constructed, with the structures ranging from 3D (4,8)-connected flu net (1), 3D 12-connected {312.440.512.62} net (2), 2-fold interpenetrated 3D (3,8)-connected tfz-d net (3), to 3D (3,7)-connected {4.62}­{47.614} net (4). Besides, magnetic measurements indicate that 1 and 3 have the antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between the adjacent MnII ions of the SBUs. Moreover, the fluorescent measurements show 2 and 4 exhibit highly selective and sensitive detection for Cr3+ cations and nitrobenzene derivatives.

Besides, magnetic measurements indicate that 1 and 3 have the antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between the adjacent MnII ions of the SBUs. Moreover, the fluorescent measurements show 2 and 4 exhibit highly selective and sensitive detection for Cr3+ cations and nitrobenzene derivatives.

A mixture of H3TCPB (0.004 mmol, 1.9 mg), MnCl2·4H2O (0.008 mmol, 1.6 mg), and 1 mL of a DMF/H2O solution (v/v = 1/1) was added to a glass tube, then pumped to a near-vacuum, heated at 95 °C for 3000 min, and cooled to 25 °C with a cooling rate of 5 °C/h. Colorless block crystals of 1 were obtained with the yield of ca. 46% (based on H3TCPB). Anal. calcd. for C54H38Mn3O24: C, 52.48; H, 3.10 (%). Found: C, 51.97; H, 3.21 (%). IR (cm–1, KBr): 3465 (m), 2363 (m), 1595 (vs), 1542 (s), 1404 (s), 1232 (s), 1160 (s), 1113 (m), 1001 (m), 875 (m), 777 (s), 625 (m), 534 (w).

Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All the reagents were commercially obtained and used directly. And the instrument as well as the test conditions are the same as those of the references unless specifically mentioned. 

Preparation of {[Mn1.5(TCPB)(H2O)(μ2-OH2)]⋅H2O} n  (1)

A mixture of H3TCPB (0.004 mmol, 1.9 mg), MnCl2⋅4H2O (0.008 mmol, 1.6 mg), and 1 mL of a DMF/H2O solution (v/v = 1/1) was added to a glass tube, then pumped to a near-vacuum, heated at 95 °C for 3000 min, and cooled to 25 °C with a cooling rate of 5 °C/h. Colorless block crystals of 1 were obtained with the yield of ca. 46% (based on H3TCPB). Anal. calcd. for C54H38Mn3O24: C, 52.48; H, 3.10 (%). Found: C, 51.97; H, 3.21 (%). IR (cm-1, KBr): 3465 (m), 2363 (m), 1595 (vs), 1542 (s), 1404 (s), 1232 (s), 1160 (s), 1113 (m), 1001 (m), 875 (m), 777 (s), 625 (m), 534 (w).

Colorless block crystals of 2 were obtained with the yield of ca. 63% (based on H3TCPB). Anal. Calcd for C108H80Cd7O47: C, 44.47; H, 2.76 (%). Found: C, 44.79; H, 2.79 (%). elements.content: Single-crystal data of complexes 1–4 were collected on a Siemens SMART diffractometer with graphite-monochromatized Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Empirical absorption corrections and Lorentz polarization were applied. Those structures were resolved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 by using the package of SHELXTL-97. For 3, the disorder atoms (C34–C36 and N3) of the coordinated DMF molecules were refined with split positions and an occupancy ratio of 58.9:41.1. In complex 4, two disordered atoms of the formates (C14 and O5) were refined as 3 with an occupancy ratio being 45:55. Detailed crystallographic data and structural refinements of complexes 1–4 were gathered in Table S1. Table S2 presents the selected angles and bond distances for complexes 1–4. Further details on the crystal structure investigations of the title complexes can be obtained from http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/ by quoting the depository number CCDC–1562146–1562149 for 1–4, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single-crystal data of complexes 1-4 were collected on a Siemens SMART diffractometer with graphite-monochromatized Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Empirical absorption corrections and Lorentz polarization were applied. Those structures were resolved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 by using the package of SHELXTL-97. For 3, the disorder atoms (C34-C36 and N3) of the coordinated DMF molecules were refined with split positions and an occupancy ratio of 58.9:41.1. In complex 4, two disordered atoms of the formates (C14 and O5) were refined as 3 with an occupancy ratio being 45:55. Detailed crystallographic data and structural refinements of complexes 1-4 were gathered in Table S1. Table S2 presents the selected angles and bond distances for complexes 1-4. Further details on the crystal structure investigations of the title complexes can be obtained from http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/ by quoting the depository number CCDC-1562146-1562149 for 1-4, respectively.

elements.content: Although this CP and its photoluminescence have been reported by Liu and co-workers, we systematically studied the structure and magnetic property of 1 here. Complex 1 crystallizes in triclinic system with space group P1̅. As can been seen form , there are one and a half of crystallographically independent MnII cations, one TCPB3– ligand, one μ2-coordinated water molecule, one coordinated water molecule, and one lattice water molecule in the asymmetric unit of 1. And Mn1 is centrosymmetric and surrounded by four carboxyl oxygen atoms (O1, and O11) and two μ2-H2O, leaving a distorted {MnO6} octahedral geometry. While Mn2 is located in a distorted {MnO6} octahedral coordination geometry, linked by four carboxyl oxygen atoms (O8, O2D, O5E, and O5F), one μ2-coordinated water molecule (O9), and one H2O molecule (O10). Besides, the Mn–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.070(1)–2.311(3) Å.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Description of {[Mn1.5(TCPB)(H2O)(μ2-OH2)]⋅H2O}n (1)

Although this CP and its photoluminescence have been reported by Liu and co-workers, we systematically studied the structure and magnetic property of 1 here. Complex 1 crystallizes in triclinic system with space group P1̅. As can been seen form , there are one and a half of crystallographically independent MnII cations, one TCPB3- ligand, one μ2-coordinated water molecule, one coordinated water molecule, and one lattice water molecule in the asymmetric unit of 1. And Mn1 is centrosymmetric and surrounded by four carboxyl oxygen atoms (O1, and O11) and two μ2-H2O, leaving a distorted {MnO6} octahedral geometry. While Mn2 is located in a distorted {MnO6} octahedral coordination geometry, linked by four carboxyl oxygen atoms (O8, O2D, O5E, and O5F), one μ2-coordinated water molecule (O9), and one H2O molecule (O10). Besides, the Mn-O bond lengths are in the range of 2.070(1)-2.311(3) Å.

elements.content: Asymmetric unit of 1 (symmetry codes: A: 1 – x, 2 – y, −z; B: 1 – x, 2 – y, 1 – z; C: x, y, −1 + z; D: x, y, 1 + z; E: −1 + x, y, z; F: 1 – x, 1 – y, 2 – z).
elements.clean_text: 1  Asymmetric unit of 1 (symmetry codes: A: 1 - x, 2 - y, -z; B: 1 - x, 2 - y, 1 - z; C: x, y, -1 + z; D: x, y, 1 + z; E: -1 + x, y, z; F: 1 - x, 1 - y, 2 - z).

elements.content: In the formation of 1, the H3TCPB ligand is completely deprotonated and adopts (κ0-κ2)-(κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ6 coordination mode (Mode I, see ), with the dihedral angles of α, β, γ, δ, ε, and ζ (α, β, γ, δ, ε, and ζ correspond to the dihedral angles between rings A/B, A/C, A/D, B/C, B/D, and C/D, details seen and and ) being 83.93°, 49.63°, 10.03°, 55.15°, 89.62°, and 50.05°, respectively. The bridging μ2–η1:η1 carboxyl groups cooperated with the bridging μ2–η2 carboxyl groups of the TCPB3– ligands as well as the μ2-coordinated water molecule, successfully forming an interesting 1D rod-like {Mn3(COO)8­(μ2-H2O)2} n SBUs, in which the Mn···Mn distances being 3.663 Å (Mn1···Mn2C), 3.507 Å (Mn2···Mn2H, symmetry code: H: −x, 1 – y, 2 – z) (). The μ6-TCPB3– ligands connected the 1D rod-like {Mn3(COO)8­(μ2-H2O)2} n SBUs to construct a 3D framework finally (a).

The bridging μ2-η1:η1 carboxyl groups cooperated with the bridging μ2-η2 carboxyl groups of the TCPB3- ligands as well as the μ2-coordinated water molecule, successfully forming an interesting 1D rod-like {Mn3(COO)8(μ2-H2O)2} n  SBUs, in which the Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn distances being 3.663 Å (Mn1⋅⋅⋅Mn2C), 3.507 Å (Mn2⋅⋅⋅Mn2H, symmetry code: H: -x, 1 - y, 2 - z) (). The μ6-TCPB3- ligands connected the 1D rod-like {Mn3(COO)8(μ2-H2O)2} n  SBUs to construct a 3D framework finally (a).

Topological analysis shows that complex 1 is a 2-nodal 4,8-connected net with stoichiometry of (4-c)2(8-c), where the TCPB3– ligands and the trinuclear {Mn3(COO)8­(μ2-H2O)2} SBUs (Figure S1) are regarded as 4-connectd and 8-connected nodes, respectively (b and Figure S2). Thus, the point symbol of 1 is {412.612.84}­{46}2, with the topological type being flu/fluorite; sqc169 (topos&RCSR.ttd).

elements.content: Complex 2 crystallizes in monoclinic system C2/c. And the asymmetric unit consists of three and a half of CdII cations, two TCPB3– ligands, three coordinated H2O molecules, one μ2-coordinated water molecule, one μ3-OH–, and one H2O molecule. As can be seen in , there are four different CdII ions with interesting coordination geometry. Cd1 and Cd4 are located in the similar distorted {CdO6} octahedron geometry, completed by four carboxyl oxygen atoms, one μ3-OH–, and one coordinated H2O molecule (μ2-coordinated H2O for Cd4). Cd2 lies in a fascinating {CdO6} wedge-shaped coordination geometry, which has the rotation symmetry axis of L2, surrounded by four carboxyl oxygen atoms (O10, O11, O10D, and O11D), and two coordinated water molecules (O12, and O12D). Cd3 is seven coordinated and linked by four carboxyl oxygen atoms (O15, O7H, O22I, and O23I), one μ3-OH– (O5H), one μ2-coordinated water molecule (O4G), and one H2O molecule (O16), exhibiting a pentagonal bipyramid coordination geometry. Besides, the bond lengths of Cd–O are in the range of 2.188(8)–2.621(7) Å.

Structural Description of {[Cd3.5(TCPB)2(H2O)3(μ2-OH2)(μ3-OH)]⋅H2O} n  (2)

Complex 2 crystallizes in monoclinic system C2/c. And the asymmetric unit consists of three and a half of CdII cations, two TCPB3- ligands, three coordinated H2O molecules, one μ2-coordinated water molecule, one μ3-OH-, and one H2O molecule. As can be seen in , there are four different CdII ions with interesting coordination geometry. Cd1 and Cd4 are located in the similar distorted {CdO6} octahedron geometry, completed by four carboxyl oxygen atoms, one μ3-OH-, and one coordinated H2O molecule (μ2-coordinated H2O for Cd4). Cd2 lies in a fascinating {CdO6} wedge-shaped coordination geometry, which has the rotation symmetry axis of L2, surrounded by four carboxyl oxygen atoms (O10, O11, O10D, and O11D), and two coordinated water molecules (O12, and O12D). Cd3 is seven coordinated and linked by four carboxyl oxygen atoms (O15, O7H, O22I, and O23I), one μ3-OH- (O5H), one μ2-coordinated water molecule (O4G), and one H2O molecule (O16), exhibiting a pentagonal bipyramid coordination geometry. Besides, the bond lengths of Cd-O are in the range of 2.188(8)-2.621(7) Å.

elements.content: Asymmetric unit of 2 (symmetry codes: A: 1/2 + x, −1/2 + y, z; B: 1 – x, y, 1/2 – z; C: 1/2 – x, −1/2 + y, 1/2 – z; D: 1 – x, y, 3/2 – z; E: 1 – x, −y, −z; F: 1 – x, −1 + y, 1/2 – z; G: 1/2 – x, 1/2 + y, 1/2 – z; H: x, 1 + y, z; I: 1/2 – x, 3/2 – y, −z.).

The H3TCPB ligand is partly deprotonated in the assembly of 2, it adopts two distinct coordination modes of (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ0)-(κ1-κ2)-μ5 (Mode II, with the dihedral angles of α, β, γ, δ, ε, and ζ being 69.95°, 49.48°, 71.64°, 68.67°, 72.22°, and 32.43°) vs (κ1-κ2)-(κ2-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ7 (Mode III, with the dihedral angles of α, β, γ, δ, ε, and ζ being 58.11°, 71.07°, 88.45°, 70.35°, 74.06°, and 35.62°). It is noteworthy that the bridging μ2–η1:η1 and the bridging + chelating μ3–η2:η1 of the Mode II TCPB3– ligand, the bridging μ3–η2:η1 carboxyl groups of the Mode III TCPB3– ligand, the μ2-coordinated H2O, as well as the μ3-OH– anions cooperated with each other to bridge Cd1, Cd3, and Cd4 ions, successfully forming a novel 1D {Cd6(COO)12(μ3-OH)2­(μ2-OH2)2} n SBUs (), in which the nearest Cd···Cd distances are 3.701 Å for Cd1···Cd4B, 4.139 Å for Cd1···Cd3C, 3.726 Å for Cd4···Cd3F, 3.960 Å for Cd1···Cd3J, 3.807 Å for Cd1···Cd4K, and 3.857 Å for Cd3···Cd4O (symmetry codes: O: −1/2 + x, 3/2 + y, z; K: −1/2 + x, 1/2 + y, z; J: x, −1 + y, z). And the two kinds of TCPB3– ligands coordinate with the 1D {Cd6(COO)12­(μ3-OH)2­(μ2-OH2)2} n SBUs to form a 3D network (Figure S3), which can be further expanded into a 3D framework (a) with the help of Cd2 ions.

elements.content: As can be seen above, each {Cd6(COO)12­(μ3-OH)2­(μ2-OH2)2} unit (Figure S4) is surrounded by 12 different TCPB3– ligands, and two kinds of TCPB3– ligands act as bridges to link {Cd6(COO)12­(μ3-OH)2­(μ2-OH2)2} unit, and Cd2 ions as linkers. Thus, the whole framework of 2 can topologically be described as a 12-connected with the point symbol of {312.440.512.62} after the {Cd6(COO)12­(μ3-OH)2­(μ2-OH2)2} unit is regarded as the 12-connected node (b and Figure S5). And similar 12-connected nets of CPs have been reported previously.

elements.content: Structural analysis reveals that complex 3 is a trinuclear {Mn3(COO)6} SBUs based 3D 3,8-c tfz-d net, and it crystallizes in triclinic system P1̅ space group, and there are one and a half of MnII cations, one TCPB3– ligand, a half of bib linkers, and one coordinated DMF molecule in the asymmetric unit (a). Mn1 is located in a centrosymmetric distorted {MnO6} octahedral geometry, linked by six carboxyl oxygen atoms from six TCPB3– ligands. And Mn2 lies in the center of a distorted {MnO5N} octahedral coordination geometry, surrounded by four carboxyl oxygen atoms from three different TCPB3– ligands, one oxygen atom form DMF, and one nitrogen atom from bib linker. Besides, the bond lengths of Mn–O are in the range of 2.188(8)–2.621(7) Å, and those of Mn–N are 2.193(8) Å, respectively.

Mn1 is located in a centrosymmetric distorted {MnO6} octahedral geometry, linked by six carboxyl oxygen atoms from six TCPB3- ligands. Besides, the bond lengths of Mn-O are in the range of 2.188(8)-2.621(7) Å, and those of Mn-N are 2.193(8) Å, respectively.

elements.content: Difference from that in 1, the H3TCPB ligand adopts (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ2)-(κ1-κ1)-μ7 coordination mode (Mode IV) in complex 3, with the dihedral angles of α, β, γ, δ, ε, and ζ being 80.68°, 50.30°, 88.11°, 84.26°, 57.89°, and 51.53°, respectively. Interestingly, the bridging μ2–η1:η1 carboxyl groups cooperate with the chelating + bridging μ3–η1:η2:η1 carboxyl groups to link with the MnII cations, successfully constructing a trinuclear {Mn3(COO)6} SBUs (b), in which the Mn1···Mn2 distances are 3.645 Å, and Mn2···Mn2E distances are 7.290 Å, respectively.

Interestingly, the bridging μ2-η1:η1 carboxyl groups cooperate with the chelating + bridging μ3-η1:η2:η1 carboxyl groups to link with the MnII cations, successfully constructing a trinuclear {Mn3(COO)6} SBUs (b), in which the Mn1⋅⋅⋅Mn2 distances are 3.645 Å, and Mn2⋅⋅⋅Mn2E distances are 7.290 Å, respectively.

elements.content: Each μ7-TCPB3– linker connects with three {Mn3(COO)6} SBUs to obtain a 2D [Mn3(TCPB)2]n motif along the a axis successfully (a). And the bib ligands bridge the 2D [Mn3(TCPB)2] n motifs to form a 3D network with an interesting 1D quadrilateral channels (13.468 Å × 14.300 Å) (b). And the large channels make those nets possibly interpenetrate with each other, finally leaving a 2-fold 3D framework (c). Topological analysis reveals that the single net can be considered as a 2-nodal 3,8-c net with stoichiometry (3-c)2(8-c) by denoting the trinuclear {Mn3(COO)6} SBUs to 8-c nodes, the TCPB3– ligands to 3-c nodes, respectively. And the topological type of 3 is tfz-d; UO3 (topos&RCSR.ttd), with the point symbol being {43}2{46.618.84} (a and Figure S6). Besides, the two interpenetrating net of the final structure is shown in b, with the full interpenetration vectors (FIV): [1,0,0] (10.92A), and PIC: [2,0,0]­[0,1,0]­[1,0,1̅] (PICVR = 2); Zt = 2, Zn = 1; Class Ia, Z = 2.

And the large channels make those nets possibly interpenetrate with each other, finally leaving a 2-fold 3D framework (c). Topological analysis reveals that the single net can be considered as a 2-nodal 3,8-c net with stoichiometry (3-c)2(8-c) by denoting the trinuclear {Mn3(COO)6} SBUs to 8-c nodes, the TCPB3- ligands to 3-c nodes, respectively. And the topological type of 3 is tfz-d; UO3 (topos&RCSR.ttd), with the point symbol being {43}2{46.618.84} (a and Figure S6). Besides, the two interpenetrating net of the final structure is shown in b, with the full interpenetration vectors (FIV): [1,0,0] (10.92A), and PIC: [2,0,0][0,1,0][1,0,1̅] (PICVR = 2); Zt = 2, Zn = 1; Class Ia, Z = 2.

elements.content: The formates which generated by DMF in-situ reaction make the complex 4 more complicated and finally giving a 3D (3,7)-c net with 1D {Cd2(COO)2(HCOO)} n chain. Complex 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic system C2/c space group. Two CdII cations, one TCPB3– ligand, one formate, one bib linker, one coordinated water molecule, and a half of free dioxane molecules are included in the asymmetric unit of 4 (). Cd1 is surrounded by five carboxyl oxygen atoms (O3, O8E, O9E, O11F, and O12F) from three TCPB3– ligands, one O4 atom from formate, and one coordinated water molecule, and presenting a distorted {CdO7} pentagonal bipyramid geometry. Cd2 lies in the center of a distorted {CdO4N2} octahedron coordination geometry, surrounded by three carboxyl oxygen atoms (O2A, O8B, and O11C), O5 from formate, and two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N3) from two different bib linkers. Besides, the bond lengths of Cd–O are in the range of 2.210(4)–2.470(7) Å, and those of Cd–N are 2.277(3) Å and 2.297(2) Å.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description of {[Cd2(TCPB)(HCOO)(bib)(H2O)]⋅0.5dioxane} n  (4)

The formates which generated by DMF in-situ reaction make the complex 4 more complicated and finally giving a 3D (3,7)-c net with 1D {Cd2(COO)2(HCOO)} n  chain. Complex 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic system C2/c space group. Two CdII cations, one TCPB3- ligand, one formate, one bib linker, one coordinated water molecule, and a half of free dioxane molecules are included in the asymmetric unit of 4 (). Cd1 is surrounded by five carboxyl oxygen atoms (O3, O8E, O9E, O11F, and O12F) from three TCPB3- ligands, one O4 atom from formate, and one coordinated water molecule, and presenting a distorted {CdO7} pentagonal bipyramid geometry. Cd2 lies in the center of a distorted {CdO4N2} octahedron coordination geometry, surrounded by three carboxyl oxygen atoms (O2A, O8B, and O11C), O5 from formate, and two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N3) from two different bib linkers. Besides, the bond lengths of Cd-O are in the range of 2.210(4)-2.470(7) Å, and those of Cd-N are 2.277(3) Å and 2.297(2) Å.

elements.content: Asymmetric unit of 4 (symmetry codes: A: x, 1 – y, 1/2 + z; B: 1/2 + x, 1/2 – y, 1/2 + z; C: 1/2 + x, 3/2 – y, 1/2 + z; D: 3/2 – x, 3/2 – y, 1 – z; E: 1/2 + x, 1/2 + y, z; F: 1/2 + x, −1/2 + y, z; G: 3/2 – x, 1/2 – y, 1 – z).

In 4, the TCPB3– adopts (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ2)-(κ1-κ2)-μ8 coordination mode (Mode V), with the dihedral angles of α, β, γ, δ, ε, and ζ being 78.38°, 78.05°, 84.40°, 84.56°, 73.44°, and 11.77°, respectively. The bridging μ2-η1:η1 as well as the chelating + bridging μ3-η1:η2:η1 carboxyl groups coordinate with CdII cations to form a binuclear {Cd2(COO)3} SBUs (Cd1A···Cd2 = 3.597 Å, Figure S7), which is further expanded by the formates into a 1D {Cd2(COO)2­(HCOO)} n chain with the binuclear {Cd2(COO)3} n SBUs distance being 8.843 Å (Figure S8). Each μ8-TCPB3– linker connects with three {Cd2(COO)3} SBUs, successfully obtaining a 2D [Cd2(TCPB)] n sheet with the opening area being 18.230 Å × 12.666 Å (a). And the formates further expanded the 2D [Cd2(TCPB)] n sheets into a 3D [Cd2(TCPB)­(HCOO)] n network with the area of the containing 1D channel being 16.564 Å × 6.453 Å (b). It is worth noting that two adjacent 3D [Cd2(TCPB)­(HCOO)] n networks interpenetrated with each other in 4 (a). Moreover, the bib linkers bridge Cd2 ions to generate a 1D {Cd­(bib)} n chain, and the separations of Cd···Cd are 14.001 Å, and 14.243 Å (Figure S9). With the 1D {Cd­(bib)} n chains as the wear lines, the two interpenetrating [Cd2(TCPB)­(HCOO)] n nets hinged together into a 3D framework (c).

elements.content: To check the phase purity, the samples of complexes 1–4 were characterized by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). As can be seen in Figure S10, the experimental PXRD patterns are almost similar to the simulated ones for 1–4. Thermogravimetric analyses were investigated for 1–4 (Figure S11). For 1, the weight loss of 8.91% is attributed to the loss of coordinated and lattice water molecules between 100 and 210 °C (calcd: 8.74%). Then the whole structure began to collapse above 405 °C. At first, the weight loss between 130 and 210 °C is owed to the loss of free and coordinated water molecules of 7.51% for 2 (calcd: 7.34%), and then the framework broke down at around 380 °C. For 3, the weight loss of 9.86% is the loss of coordinated DMF molecules below 220 °C (calcd: 9.83%). Then the organic linkers began to degrade about 350 °C. For 4, the initial weight loss of 6.7% in temperature range of 120–265 °C belongs to the loss of a half of free dioxane molecules and a coordinated water molecule (calcd: 6.1%). and then the framework began to collapse.

X-ray Powder Diffraction Analyses and Thermogravimetric Analyses

To check the phase purity, the samples of complexes 1-4 were characterized by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). As can be seen in Figure S10, the experimental PXRD patterns are almost similar to the simulated ones for 1-4. Thermogravimetric analyses were investigated for 1-4 (Figure S11). For 1, the weight loss of 8.91% is attributed to the loss of coordinated and lattice water molecules between 100 and 210 °C (calcd: 8.74%). Then the whole structure began to collapse above 405 °C. At first, the weight loss between 130 and 210 °C is owed to the loss of free and coordinated water molecules of 7.51% for 2 (calcd: 7.34%), and then the framework broke down at around 380 °C. For 3, the weight loss of 9.86% is the loss of coordinated DMF molecules below 220 °C (calcd: 9.83%). Then the organic linkers began to degrade about 350 °C. For 4, the initial weight loss of 6.7% in temperature range of 120-265 °C belongs to the loss of a half of free dioxane molecules and a coordinated water molecule (calcd: 6.1%). and then the framework began to collapse.

elements.content: The fluorescence spectra of 2 and 4 were examined at room temperature in the solid state. As can be seen from Figure S12, the free H3TCPB ligand displays a strong peak at 342 nm, which may be assigned to π–π* transitions of the benzene rings. The emission spectra of complexes 2 and 4 exhibit strong emission peaks at 346 nm for 2 and 314 nm for 4, respectively (λex = 280 nm). The emission peak of complex 2 is in accordance with that of the free H3TCPB ligand. While the emission spectrum of 4 has a clear blue shift (Δ = 26 nm) because of the introduction of auxiliary ligand bib. It is worth noting that the emission peak of 4 is analogous to that of bib (λex = 280 nm). Thus, this phenomenon can be attributed to the mixed effects of intra-ligand and ligand-to-ligand charge transitions.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties and Sensing of Small Organic Molecules and Nitrobenzene Derivatives

The fluorescence spectra of 2 and 4 were examined at room temperature in the solid state. As can be seen from Figure S12, the free H3TCPB ligand displays a strong peak at 342 nm, which may be assigned to π-π* transitions of the benzene rings. The emission spectra of complexes 2 and 4 exhibit strong emission peaks at 346 nm for 2 and 314 nm for 4, respectively (λex = 280 nm). The emission peak of complex 2 is in accordance with that of the free H3TCPB ligand. While the emission spectrum of 4 has a clear blue shift (Δ = 26 nm) because of the introduction of auxiliary ligand bib. It is worth noting that the emission peak of 4 is analogous to that of bib (λex = 280 nm). Thus, this phenomenon can be attributed to the mixed effects of intra-ligand and ligand-to-ligand charge transitions.

elements.content: To explore the sensibilities of complexes 2 and 4, DMF, DMSO, ethanol, acetonitrile, n-butyl alcohol, and acetone were selected for the luminescent sensing studies. Two milligram samples of 2 and 4 were dispersed in 2 mL diverse solvents with ultrasonication of 30 min. As shown in , both 2 and 4 display the strongest luminescent intensity in DMF, while exhibiting the weakest in acetone, with the intensity sort being DMF > acetonitrile > n-butyl alcohol > DMSO > ethanol > acetone. The recognition mechanism of organic solvents may be attributed to the interactions between the different structures of the Cd–CPs and different polarities of the solvent molecules.

elements.content: The nitroaromatics (NACs) are important chemical raw materials and are extensively applied in leather, dyes, and the glass industry, which can cause explosions and have hazards. Therefore, effective and fast detection of NACs is vital to the environment and personal safety. Herein, we selected series of nitroaromatics (NACs) (p-nitrotoluene (PNT), nitrobenzene (NB), p-nitrophenol (PNP), and p-nitroaniline (PNA)) as representatives to study the recognition of 2 and 4 for NACs, systemically. The DMF solutions of PNT, NB, PNP, and PNA with different concentrations were tested and given in , and it can be seen that the fluorescent intensities of emulsions decreased with increasing concentrations of the DMF solution. When the concentrations of nitroaromatics in the suspension solution are up to 0.1 mM, the quenching rates of the Cd–CPs are listed in . The curves of the I 0 /I versus the concentration of NCVs are presented in Figures S13–S20 to further test the quenching efficiency (I 0 and I are the fluorescent intensity without and with the addition the analyte, respectively). And the I 0 /I versus nitroaromatics concentration plots show a bend upward, which may be attributed to the coexistence of static and dynamic quenching. The related parameters of the Stern–Volmer curves are listed in . The values of K SV are measured when the concentrations of NDVs are up to 10 μM (Figures S21 and S22). As it can be found that the orders of quenching constants for NCVs are PNP > PNA > NB > PNT (2) and PNT > PNP > NB > PNA (4), respectively. Notably, this order is not fully in accordance with the trend of electron-withdrawing groups. The reasons for this phenomenon are as follows: First, the structural difference of complexes 2 and 4. The H3TCPB ligand is partly and completely deprotonated in 2 and 4, respectively. Furthermore, the auxiliary ligand (bib) and formats took part in the construction of 4; second, the weak interactions between CPs and nitro-containing analytes may lead to the different orders; lastly, other factors might be one of the important causes, including electron-withdrawing ability, electric properties, and vapor pressure of the analytes. So, we speculate that the reasons for different orders are attributed to the mixed result of the above-mentioned factors. As shown in Figures S23 and S24, the quenching decay is very small after three cycles; the results exhibit that 2 and 4 can be recovered and reproduced by washing with DMF and filtration. Meanwhile, the PXRD patterns of samples after the quenching experiments were similar to the simulated one, indicating the complexes have good recyclability and stability as chemical sensors (Figures S25 and S26).

The possible quenching mechanisms of nitrobenzene derivatives are as follows: (1) The inductive effect of the photoinduced electron transfer mechanism. The lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) of electron-deficient NACs locate in somewhere between the conduction band (CB) and valence band (VB) of the CPs. The excited electrons from the CB of the CPs can be transferred to the LUMO orbitals of NACs upon excitation, resulting in a quenching effect; (2) to manifest whether resonance energy transfer (RET) exists or not in the sensing process, the UV–vis spectra of NACs dispersed in 2 and 4 suspensions were investigated, and the results present that NACs have wide absorption bands from 300 to 550 nm, which overlap with the excitation and/or emission bands of complexes 2 and 4 (Figure S27), showing RET exists in the quenching experiment.

elements.content: The sensing abilities of 2 and 4 for different M­(NO3) x (0.01 M, and M = Na+, Mn2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Hg2+, K+, Ca2+, Ba2+, Cu2+, Mg2+, Al3+, Cr3+) were studied in water at 25 °C. As can be seen from the , the luminescent intensity of M n+@CPs was varied with different metal ions. The results show that Cr3+ cations for 2 and 4 have better luminescent quenching effects.

Detection of Metal Cations

The sensing abilities of 2 and 4 for different M(NO3) x  (0.01 M, and M = Na+, Mn2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Hg2+, K+, Ca2+, Ba2+, Cu2+, Mg2+, Al3+, Cr3+) were studied in water at 25 °C. As can be seen from the , the luminescent intensity of M n+@CPs was varied with different metal ions. The results show that Cr3+ cations for 2 and 4 have better luminescent quenching effects.

elements.clean_text: 15  Luminescence intensities of 2 and 4 in 0.01 M aqueous solutions of metal cations.

elements.content: The relationship between the concentration of Cr3+ cations and the luminescent intensity of Cd–CPs suspensions was studied simultaneously. It can be seen from Figures S28 and S29 that the fluorescent intensities of 2 and 4 present an obvious quenching effect with increasing addition of Cr3+ cations, and the quenching rate is 96.90% for 2 when the concentration of Cr3+ is up to 0.13 mM, and 97.67% for 4 when the [Cr3+] is up to 0.1 mM. The nonlinearities of Stern–Volmer curves for Cr3+@CdCPs in aqueous system conform to the exponential equations of I 0 /I = 1.35e2065[Cr3+] – 0.25 for 2, and I 0 /I = 2.10e2920[Cr3+] – 1.47 for 4, respectively. And the SV plots are typically linear when the [Cr3+] is 0.015 mM, the K SV value of 5.6 × 104 M–1 for 2, and 3.8 × 104 M–1 for 4 (Figure S30).
elements.clean_text: The relationship between the concentration of Cr3+ cations and the luminescent intensity of Cd-CPs suspensions was studied simultaneously. It can be seen from Figures S28 and S29 that the fluorescent intensities of 2 and 4 present an obvious quenching effect with increasing addition of Cr3+ cations, and the quenching rate is 96.90% for 2 when the concentration of Cr3+ is up to 0.13 mM, and 97.67% for 4 when the [Cr3+] is up to 0.1 mM. The nonlinearities of Stern-Volmer curves for Cr3+@CdCPs in aqueous system conform to the exponential equations of I 0 /I = 1.35e2065[Cr3+] - 0.25 for 2, and I 0 /I = 2.10e2920[Cr3+] - 1.47 for 4, respectively. And the SV plots are typically linear when the [Cr3+] is 0.015 mM, the K SV value of 5.6 × 104 M-1 for 2, and 3.8 × 104 M-1 for 4 (Figure S30).

elements.content: To further investigate the anti-interference abilities of other metal ions to quenching selectivity of 2 and 4 for Cr3+, the luminescent sensing of 2 and 4 suspensions for Cr3+ ions was investigated in the presence of other metal cations. The results indicate that there exists hardly any effect on the exploration of Cr3+ (Figure S31). Furthermore, the PXRD patterns of samples after fluorescent experiments are consistent with the simulated one, demonstrating that the structures of 2 and 4 do not change (Figures S25 and S26). Meanwhile, it can be seen from Figure S32 that the fluorescent intensities of complexes did not show significant change, and this result shows 2 and 4 have good regenerative abilities after three cycles. Therefore, 2 and 4 can sense the Cr3+ cations in aqueous solution. On the basis of the above-mentioned results, the possible quenching mechanisms of 2 and 4 for NACs analytes might be as follows: (1) the competition absorption for the excitation energy between the Cr3+ and CPs frameworks due to their weak interactions or the bonding interactions; (2) researchers have found that the overlap of absorption by the analytes with the excitation and/or emission of the complexes might cause the intermolecular energy transfer. In order to verify the absence or presence of the intermolecular energy transfer in our system, the UV–vis spectra of Cr3+ in aqueous solution of 2 and 4 were carried out, and the results show that Cr3+ has wide absorption bands from 300 to 650 nm, which overlap with the excitation and/or emission bands of complexes 2 and 4 (Figure S33).

On the basis of the above-mentioned results, the possible quenching mechanisms of 2 and 4 for NACs analytes might be as follows: (1) the competition absorption for the excitation energy between the Cr3+ and CPs frameworks due to their weak interactions or the bonding interactions; (2) researchers have found that the overlap of absorption by the analytes with the excitation and/or emission of the complexes might cause the intermolecular energy transfer. In order to verify the absence or presence of the intermolecular energy transfer in our system, the UV-vis spectra of Cr3+ in aqueous solution of 2 and 4 were carried out, and the results show that Cr3+ has wide absorption bands from 300 to 650 nm, which overlap with the excitation and/or emission bands of complexes 2 and 4 (Figure S33).

elements.content: In summary, four 3D CPs with diverse SBUs have been constructed, with their structures ranging from 3D (4,8)-connected flu net (1), 3D 12-connected {312.440.512.62} net (2), 2-fold interpenetrated 3D (3,8)-connected tfz-d net (3), to 3D (3,7)-connected {4.62}­{47.614} net (4). The magnetic investigation indicated complexes 1 and 3 have antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between adjacent MnII ions. And the fluorescence measurements show 2 and 4 exhibit highly sensitive and selective detection for Cr3+ cations and nitrobenzene derivatives.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, four 3D CPs with diverse SBUs have been constructed, with their structures ranging from 3D (4,8)-connected flu net (1), 3D 12-connected {312.440.512.62} net (2), 2-fold interpenetrated 3D (3,8)-connected tfz-d net (3), to 3D (3,7)-connected {4.62}{47.614} net (4). The magnetic investigation indicated complexes 1 and 3 have antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between adjacent MnII ions. And the fluorescence measurements show 2 and 4 exhibit highly sensitive and selective detection for Cr3+ cations and nitrobenzene derivatives.

All the reagents were commercially obtained and used directly. And the instrument as well as the test conditions are the same as those of the references unless specifically mentioned.

Preparation of {[Mn<sub>1.5</sub>(TCPB)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)­(μ<sub>2</sub>-OH<sub>2</sub>)]·H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of H3TCPB (0.004 mmol, 1.9 mg), MnCl2·4H2O (0.008 mmol, 1.6 mg), and 1 mL of a DMF/H2O solution (v/v = 1/1) was added to a glass tube, then pumped to a near-vacuum, heated at 95 °C for 3000 min, and cooled to 25 °C with a cooling rate of 5 °C/h. Colorless block crystals of 1 were obtained with the yield of ca. 46% (based on H3TCPB). Anal. calcd. for C54H38Mn3O24: C, 52.48; H, 3.10 (%). Found: C, 51.97; H, 3.21 (%). IR (cm–1, KBr): 3465 (m), 2363 (m), 1595 (vs), 1542 (s), 1404 (s), 1232 (s), 1160 (s), 1113 (m), 1001 (m), 875 (m), 777 (s), 625 (m), 534 (w).

Preparation of {[Cd<sub>3.5</sub>(TCPB)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>­(μ<sub>2</sub>-OH<sub>2</sub>)­(μ<sub>3</sub>-OH)]­·H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of H3TCPB (0.004 mmol, 1.9 mg), Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (0.008 mmol, 2.5 mg), and 1 mL mixed solution of DMF/ETOH/H2O (v/v/v = 1/1/2) was added to a hard glass tube, pumped to a near-vacuum, heated at 120 °C for 50 h, and cooled to 25 °C with a decreasing rate of 2 °C/h. Colorless block crystals of 2 were obtained with the yield of ca. 63% (based on H3TCPB). Anal. Calcd for C108H80Cd7O47: C, 44.47; H, 2.76 (%). Found: C, 44.79; H, 2.79 (%). IR (cm–1, KBr): 3441 (m), 1599 (vs), 1540 (s), 1496 (m), 1455 (m), 1397 (vs), 1235 (s), 1162 (m), 1118 (m), 1001 (s), 872 (m), 781 (s), 626 (m), 534 (w).

Preparation of [Mn<sub>1.5</sub>(TCPB)­(bib)<sub>0.5</sub>­(DMF)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

The mixture of H3TCPB (0.004 mmol, 1.9 mg), bib (0.008 mmol, 1.7 mg), MnCl2·4H2O (0.008 mmol, 1.6 mg), and 1 mL DMF/dioxane/H2O (v/v/v = 1/1/2) was added to a glass tube, heated at 120 °C for 50 h, and then cooled to 25 °C with a falling rate of 2 °C/h. Light yellow block crystals of 3 were obtained with the yield of ca. 57% (based on H3TCPB). Anal. Calcd for C72H54Mn3N6O20: C, 58.11; H, 3.66; N, 5.65 (%). Found: C, 58.39; H, 3.76; N, 5.59 (%). IR (cm–1, KBr): 3407 (m), 1663 (m), 1596 (vs), 1499 (m), 1397 (vs), 1221 (vs), 1162 (m), 1118 (m), 1062 (m), 1006 (s), 834 (s), 784 (vs),711 (m), 652 (m), 541 (w).

Preparation of {[Cd<sub>2</sub>(TCPB)­(HCOO)­(bib)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)]­·0.5dioxane}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

The synthesis process of 4 is similar to that of 3 except that the MnCl2·4H2O was replaced by Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O. Faint yellow block crystals of 4 were achieved with the yield of ca. 51% (based on H3TCPB). Anal. Calcd for C42H32Cd2N4O13: C, 49.19; H, 3.15; N, 5.46 (%). Found: C,49.32; H, 3.31; N, 5.38 (%). IR (cm–1, KBr): 3426 (m), 1593 (vs), 1528 (s), 1461 (m), 1394 (vs), 1303 (m), 1224 (vs), 1159 (m), 1110 (m), 1065 (m), 1016 (m), 966 (w), 837 (m), 784 (m), 737 (w), 649 (m), 532 (w).

cln_elements.content:
Each μ7-TCPB3– linker connects with three {Mn3(COO)6} SBUs to obtain a 2D [Mn3(TCPB)2]n motif along the a axis successfully (a). And the bib ligands bridge the 2D [Mn3(TCPB)2] n motifs to form a 3D network with an interesting 1D quadrilateral channels (13.468 Å × 14.300 Å) (b). And the large channels make those nets possibly interpenetrate with each other, finally leaving a 2-fold 3D framework (c). Topological analysis reveals that the single net can be considered as a 2-nodal 3,8-c net with stoichiometry (3-c)2(8-c) by denoting the trinuclear {Mn3(COO)6} SBUs to 8-c nodes, the TCPB3– ligands to 3-c nodes, respectively. And the topological type of 3 is tfz-d; UO3 (topos&RCSR.ttd), with the point symbol being {43}2{46.618.84} (a and Figure S6). Besides, the two interpenetrating net of the final structure is shown in b, with the full interpenetration vectors (FIV): [1,0,0] (10.92A), and PIC: [2,0,0]­[0,1,0]­[1,0,1̅] (PICVR = 2); Zt = 2, Zn = 1; Class Ia, Z = 2.

X-ray Powder Diffraction Analyses and Thermogravimetric Analyses

To check the phase purity, the samples of complexes 1–4 were characterized by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). As can be seen in Figure S10, the experimental PXRD patterns are almost similar to the simulated ones for 1–4. Thermogravimetric analyses were investigated for 1–4 (Figure S11). For 1, the weight loss of 8.91% is attributed to the loss of coordinated and lattice water molecules between 100 and 210 °C (calcd: 8.74%). Then the whole structure began to collapse above 405 °C. At first, the weight loss between 130 and 210 °C is owed to the loss of free and coordinated water molecules of 7.51% for 2 (calcd: 7.34%), and then the framework broke down at around 380 °C. For 3, the weight loss of 9.86% is the loss of coordinated DMF molecules below 220 °C (calcd: 9.83%). Then the organic linkers began to degrade about 350 °C. For 4, the initial weight loss of 6.7% in temperature range of 120–265 °C belongs to the loss of a half of free dioxane molecules and a coordinated water molecule (calcd: 6.1%). and then the framework began to collapse.

Luminescent Properties and Sensing of Small Organic Molecules and Nitrobenzene Derivatives

The fluorescence spectra of 2 and 4 were examined at room temperature in the solid state. As can be seen from Figure S12, the free H3TCPB ligand displays a strong peak at 342 nm, which may be assigned to π–π* transitions of the benzene rings. The emission spectra of complexes 2 and 4 exhibit strong emission peaks at 346 nm for 2 and 314 nm for 4, respectively (λex = 280 nm). The emission peak of complex 2 is in accordance with that of the free H3TCPB ligand. While the emission spectrum of 4 has a clear blue shift (Δ = 26 nm) because of the introduction of auxiliary ligand bib. It is worth noting that the emission peak of 4 is analogous to that of bib (λex = 280 nm). Thus, this phenomenon can be attributed to the mixed effects of intra-ligand and ligand-to-ligand charge transitions.

The relationship between the concentration of Cr3+ cations and the luminescent intensity of Cd–CPs suspensions was studied simultaneously. It can be seen from Figures S28 and S29 that the fluorescent intensities of 2 and 4 present an obvious quenching effect with increasing addition of Cr3+ cations, and the quenching rate is 96.90% for 2 when the concentration of Cr3+ is up to 0.13 mM, and 97.67% for 4 when the [Cr3+] is up to 0.1 mM. The nonlinearities of Stern–Volmer curves for Cr3+@CdCPs in aqueous system conform to the exponential equations of I 0 /I = 1.35e2065[Cr3+] – 0.25 for 2, and I 0 /I = 2.10e2920[Cr3+] – 1.47 for 4, respectively. And the SV plots are typically linear when the [Cr3+] is 0.015 mM, the K SV value of 5.6 × 104 M–1 for 2, and 3.8 × 104 M–1 for 4 (Figure S30).

Magnetic Properties

The crystal structures reveal that 1D rod-like {Mn3(COO)8­(μ2-H2O)2} n SBUs in 1, and trinuclear {Mn3(COO)6} n SBUs in 3 may show magnetic properties. Thus, the variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements of 1 and 3 are shown in Figures S34 and S35. For complex 1, the χM T value at room temperature is 14.3 cm3 K mol–1, and similar to three spin–only magnetically isolated MnII ions (13.2 cm3 K mol–1), which may be due to the antiferromagnetic interactions between MnII ions. With the temperature decreasing to 14.5 K, the χM T value decreases to the lowest of 7.6 cm3 K mol–1. And then the χM T value up to 13.5 cm3 K mol–1 at about 2 K. The temperature dependence χM followed the Curie–Weiss law χM = C/(T – θ) with C = 15.5 cm3 K mol–1, θ = −28.6 K (Figure S34). For complex 3, the variable-temperature susceptibility is similar to 1, with the χM T value being 13.6 cm3 K mol–1 at room temperature, according with the superposition of three spin-only magnetically isolated MnII ions (13.2 cm3 K mol–1). And then the χM T value decreases continuously to 4.3 cm3 K mol–1 with the temperature decreasing to 2 K. The temperature dependence χM also followed the Curie–Weiss law χM = C/(T – θ), with C = 14.9 cm3 K mol–1, θ = −28.8 K (Figure S35). The negative values of θ also indicate that 1 and 3 have the antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between the adjacent MnII ions.

The temperature dependence χM followed the Curie-Weiss law χM = C/(T - θ) with C = 15.5 cm3 K mol-1, θ = -28.6 K (Figure S34). For complex 3, the variable-temperature susceptibility is similar to 1, with the χM T value being 13.6 cm3 K mol-1 at room temperature, according with the superposition of three spin-only magnetically isolated MnII ions (13.2 cm3 K mol-1). And then the χM T value decreases continuously to 4.3 cm3 K mol-1 with the temperature decreasing to 2 K. The temperature dependence χM also followed the Curie-Weiss law χM = C/(T - θ), with C = 14.9 cm3 K mol-1, θ = -28.8 K (Figure S35). The negative values of θ also indicate that 1 and 3 have the antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between the adjacent MnII ions.
